body.header: Look carefully at the flow chart and complete the report by choosing the word or phrase which best fits each gap.

p.font: Subsequently: The diagram shows that the company can either run a teaser campaign or an awareness campaign. The awareness campaign doesn't follow the teaser campaign.
Prior to this: 'Prior to' means 'before'. The diagram doesn't show that first an awareness campaign is run and then a teaser campaign.
If: This is the correct answer.
Unless: 'Unless' means 'if not'.
Whether: 'Whether' can sometimes be used to mean 'if', for example in reported speech, with prepositions or after certain verbs. However, it's not appropriate here.
then: This is the correct answer.
otherwise: This can't be used because the sentence begins with 'if'.
when: The missing word here shows that something happens only if a certain condition is true.
First of all: This is the correct answer.
Firstly: This is used to introduce a list of reasons or arguments in a discursive composition.
Once: 'Once' is used to mean 'when something is completed or finished'.
Next: This is the correct answer.
Finally: If you look at the flow chart, you'll see that this isn't the final step of the three.
Initially: This means 'at first'.
Finally: This is the correct answer.
At the end: This expression isn't used to list items or stages in a process.
In the end: This expression is used in stories, not in reports like this one.
If: This is the correct answer.
Provided: 'Provided' has a similar meaning to 'if', but they are not used in exactly the same way. 'Provided' means that something will happen 'only if' a certain condition is true.

While: This is used to show that two things are happening at the same time. This sentence refers to the alternatives which the company face when they are deciding what kind of campaign to run. Go back to the top of the flow chart.
While: This is the correct answer.

After: If you look at the flow chart you'll see that the monitoring of ticket sales takes place all through the sales advertising campaign. Two stages in the process are taking place at the same time.

If: 'Ticket monitoring' is not an alternative stage in the process. If you look at the flow chart you'll see that it takes place all through the sales advertising campaign. Two stages in the process are taking place at the same time.
If: This is the correct answer.

In case: 'In case' is similar in meaning to if, but it is not appropriate here. 'In case' is used when we refer to precautions that are taken. 'Take an umbrella with you, in case it rains', for example.
Whether: 'Whether' can sometimes be used to mean 'if', for example in reported speech, with prepositions or after certain verbs. However, it's not appropriate here.
either: This is the correct answer.
or: As you've noticed, this sentence describes the alternative stages shown at the bottom of the flow chart. However, you've used the wrong connector.
neither: 'Neither' means not one and not the other.
or: This is the correct answer.
neither: 'Neither' means not one and not the other.
nor: This means 'not the other'.
On the other hand: This is the correct answer.
Finally: If you look at the flow chart you'll see that this is not the end of the process, although it is the end of the report.
Then: This sentence refers to the diamond which says, 'Are tickets selling well?' This is an 'alternative' stage.
